<body align="middle">
    <header>
        <h2>History of Mobile Computing</h2>
            <p class="author">Elizabeth St. Pierre</p>
    </header>
    <article>
        <p>Mobile computing, which we today think of as portable things like smartphones,
        laptops, and tablets, wasn’t always small and convenient to carry. An example
        of this is the first pocket calculator, the <strong>Handy LE-8OA from Busicom made in 1972</strong>.
        The Handy LE-8OA was only a four function calculator yet is the same size as some
        modern scientific calculators <a href="http://www.vintagecalculators.com/html/busicom_le-80a_handy.html">(Tout, Vin)</a>.
        <table border="0"
               cellspacing="0"
               cellpadding="0"
               class="graph">
        <tr>
            <td class="graph"><img src="http://www.vintagecalculators.com/assets/images/BusiconLE80A_2.jpg" width="200" height="300"/></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
            <td class="caption">Busicom LE-8OA made in 1972</td>
        </tr>
    </table>
               There was also the <strong>Electronic Wizard</strong>
        which was a toy for children made in the <strong>late 70’s and early 80’s.</strong> It had 6 games
        on it, so it could also be referred as one of the first mobile gaming devices.
        Furthermore, even though the Electronic Wizard was called a toy, it was one of
        the first products that slightly resembled a modern day laptop <a href="http://www.computerworlduk.com/galleries/it-vendors/milestones-in-history-of-mobile-computing-3267504/">(IDG UK, comp)</a>.
        <table border="0"
               cellpadding="0"
               cellspacing="0"
               class="graph">
            <tr>
                <td class="graph"><img src="https://zerbinator.files.wordpress.com/2015/06/parker_brothers_merlin_hand_held_electronic_game.jpg?w=584" width="300" height="200"/></td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td class="caption">Merlin Electronic Wizard made around the early 70's and the late 80's</td>
            </tr>
        </table>
        However, the actual first laptop was the <strong>Osborne 1.</strong> It was made to be carried,
        but weighed 23.5 pounds. The Osborne 1 had a handle and a keyboard that folded
        up for when you wanted to carry it <a href="http://www.computerworlduk.com/galleries/it-vendors/milestones-in-history-of-mobile-computing-3267504/">(IDG UK, comp)</a>,yet a laptop nowadays usually
        weighs around only 5 pounds <a href="http://www.ict-pulse.com/2011/06/laptops-versus-tablets-which-one-is-better/">(Marius, ICT)</a>.
        <table border="0"
               cellpadding="0"
               cellspacing="0"
               class="graph">
            <tr>
                <td class="graph"><img src="data:image/jpeg;base64,/9j/4AAQSkZJRgABAQAAAQABAAD/2wCEAAkGBxQTEhQUExQWFRUXFxcXGBgYGBgYGBgcHRcXFxcXGhgYHCggGBolHBcYITEhJSkrLi4uFx8z
                "
                                       width="300" height="200"/></td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td class="caption">The Osborne 1 made in 1981</td>
            </tr>
        </table>
        Another example of the development of
        mobile computing is the <strong>Psion.</strong> It was known as the first handheld computer, or a
        smartphone that can’t make calls, allowing the user to access a calendar and calculator
        from anywhere <a href="http://www.computerworlduk.com/galleries/it-vendors/milestones-in-history-of-mobile-computing-3267504/">(IDG UK, comp)</a>. However, a phone from the 21st century could provide
        almost anything one would like, including games and more advanced features than those
        available on the Psion. The <strong>Apple iBook from 1999</strong> was the first laptop to carry a Wi-Fi
        card, which led to the large rise in the creation of products with wireless internet
        connectivity <a href="http://www.computerworlduk.com/galleries/it-vendors/milestones-in-history-of-mobile-computing-3267504/">(IDG UK, comp)</a>. Laptops got another amazing upgrade in <strong>2002</strong>, when the <strong>Acer
        TravelMate TM-100 laptop/tablet hybrid</strong> was introduced. The Acer was the first laptop
        tablet hybrid that could turn its screen 180° and fold back on the keyboard, doubling
        as a tablet that worked with a stylus <a href="http://www.computerworlduk.com/galleries/it-vendors/milestones-in-history-of-mobile-computing-3267504/">(IDG UK, comp)</a>. Products such as the ASUS
        Chromebook and the HP Pavilion have continued the idea of a hybrid such as the Acer,
        except instead of the screen turning it now varies from detaching from the keyboard or
        just folding back. Most laptop tablet hybrids are also now touch screen, and styluses
        are optional. One of the most talked about innovations nowadays is the <strong>Google Glass.</strong>
        The Google Glass has taken ideas from science fiction of advanced technology and multi
        use glasses and made them a reality. The plans for these new glasses have been
            set back, but Google is still planning on creating them and focusing on the
            applications for technology. However, instead of doing so for everyday customers,
            they will be focusing on business like environments <a href="http://www.computerworlduk.com/galleries/it-vendors/milestones-in-history-of-mobile-computing-3267504/">(IDG UK, comp)</a>.
            <p>This development of mobile computing may seem like it took a while,
            but creations such as the Handy LE-8OA from 1972, the Osborne 1, and
            the Acer were ahead of their time, and wouldn’t be further improved until years later.
            The Handy Le-8OA was smaller than any calculator at the time (creating the concept of
            convenience), the Osborne 1 was the first computer that was meant to be carried around
            (creating the concept of portable devices), and the Acer was one of the first laptop
            tablet hybrids (creating the concept of multi-use laptops or tablets).


    </article>
</body>
</html>
